Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2010 12:17PM helena67 wrote: You know, there is no difference in prognosis really between 3 and 4 positive lymph nodes, it's just a 'cut-off' point for statistical purposes...It sounds like you are getting a good treatment. Good idea to check out the '5 years out' thread. After 2 years of struggling with this, I have finally arrived at the conclusion that my prognosis isn't too bad...Treatment for breast cancer has really advanced and chances are good that you will be fine. Talk to your Oncologist and see if he/she can reassure you. Lastly, you are very young to develop breast cancer. You can take a gene test to see if you carry a gene mutation called BRCA1 or BRCA2 - another thing to discuss with your Doc. Take care,  -H.

I do not know how long you should continue with AIs after 5 years. It might be good to have a good conversation with your Onc about this and possibly even have a second opinion for peace of mind. Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2009 11:49PM helena67 wrote: Hi Weesa, I have seen some papers on Luminal A and B - need to see if I can dig that up. But, as I recall, Luminal A designation is for those tumors that are very strongly ER positive and PR positive. Usually these tumors then tend to have a lower Ki67, which is a measure of aggressiveness of the tumor. Let's say that a tumor that is 90% ER positive and 80% PR positive with a Ki67 of 8% would be a typical Luminal A tumor. These are also HER2- (negative). I was ER positive but PR negative (<5%) and had a higher Ki67% (high is typically 13% and higher)and I was also HER2+. Thus, I had a typical Luminal B tumor. Basically, Luminal A are the more 'lazy', strongly hormone dependent tumors and Luminal B the more aggressive, but still also hormone dependent tumors. Luminal B will respond more to chemotherapy compared with Luminal A. Hope this helps a little. You are 7 years out! That is great! By the way, as a patient you have the right to get decent answers to your questions from your Onc.... Best, Helena.

Posts.Content: May 2, 2009 11:40PM helena67 wrote: Hi Roxy et al, I have always had trouble sleeping whenever I feel stressed. Never understood how my husband sleeps through just about everything! In any case, You probably should first focus on not having pain when you go to sleep. That is probably the most important thing. Otherwise you start thinking about the pain and then you cannot sleep. After many years, I have come to the realization that, for me, insomnia is a learned behavior. What works for me is sleep deprivation. Instead of going to bed, I stay up all night and just watch TV or read a book. After a night or 2 I feel so tired that I sleep fine again (sometimes with the help of a small cognac!). Good luck!

I had radiation and have not have problems so far (knock on wood). But, there have a been a lot of stories in the news recently that even a few circulating tumor cells in women with 'negative nodes' can increase risk for recurrence. I believe (and of course I am not the professional here) that with a triple negative grade 3 and large tumor, one needs to seek aggressive treatment. It is even on this breastcancer.org website if I am not mistaken. Please have a second opinion and then decide, weighing the pros and cons, and don't look back.... Best wishes to all, Helena.

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2009 04:01PM helena67 wrote: Hi Cheryl, Yup, Kerry is exactly right. You should receive either Arimidex, Femara or Aromasin. There are no 'head to head' comparative studies out yet - so we don't yet know if one is more effective that the other. I think at the moment they are all 3 considered equally good. Sometimes patients switch because they tolerate one better than the other. I have been on Femara for about 5-6 months now and tolerate it well. But there are some side effects - for example I notice stiffness in my hands and feet. Sometimes I have some trouble sleeping (although that seems to be on and off). But I have not noticed major hair loss or weight gain for example. One of the most important things to remember is that you don't quite your hormone treatment. I have read several stories and articles that quite many women throw in the towel so to speak after a year or 2. But that really can affect your risk of recurrence. Good luck! Helena.

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2009 02:22PM helena67 wrote: Are there any other really positive studies for stage III patients besides that small study from the Mayo Clinic if (I remember correctly)? Would be nice to see some more. I would be fine with all of these treatments, including side effects, if I knew ahead of time that everything will turn out fine, even in the long run. That is the problem with breast cancer treatment I think. There is no good way of checking if the treatments work as intended. Just like you can measure blood pressure to follow hypertension patients (and correct their regimen in a timely fashion, if necessary) or measure cholesterol in patients with hypercholesterolemia. But in our case, the oncologists provide average numbers and the standard 'there is no guarantee' remark. Very frustrating and unsatisfactory if you compare with other health conditions, and given that this is so serious.

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2009 04:13PM helena67 wrote: Hi, From what I have read, it is not that uncommon that menstrual periods temporarily disappear during chemo and then return after it is all done. So that is a sign you are still premenopausal. In that case, tamoxifen is a good choice. You should NOT be on an aromatase inhibitor (such as femara or arimidex) if you still get your periods. Best, Helena.
Posts.Title: anemia... helena67 KerryMac

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2009 08:47AM helena67 wrote: Thanks Sherri,  I will see what I can do - I agree with you that the bone marrow suppression will take some time. I just don't like the way I look at the moment (kind of pale and not particularly 'healthy') and the way I feel (blah). DC Mom, maybe you should go for a second opinion? I think there is no one single right answer to this question at the moment. I had an oophorectomy (based on overian cancer history in my family), so then I thought I might as well take my ovaries out to remove a source of estrogen from the breast cancer. Then, I was immediately put on an AI (Femara) and I am content with that and I don't notice too many side effects (except fatigue but that may be the anemia). However, there is a fairly recent and important Austrian study (the one that also showed a benefit for Zometa). This was a study by Michael Gnant, published in the New England Journal of Medicine in January of 2009. In this study, about 1200 premenopausal women were enrolled and it showed that over the course of 3 years there was no difference beween tamoxifen plus lupron compared with an aromatase inhibitor plus lupron. Basically, that all means that there is no clear proof that an AI would be better than Tamox in younger women, so now you see that some women (like myself) get an oophorectomy plus AI, some women (like Everyminute & Bugs) get an oophorectomy and Tamox. Some women opt for only Tamoxifen (which is still the so-called Gold Standard, or Standard of Care in premenopausal women) and finally, some women combine the Tamoxifen with Lupron. As for myself, it is quite possible that after my 5 years with AI are up, that I will continue with tamoxifen. But I don't know that yet. Finally, you also consider that an oophorectomy possibly will have long-term health effects on for example bone health, heart health, effects that are not entirely known. The surgery itself (which can be done laparoscopically) is not a big deal. So, it may be really good if you talk to another Onc about this, maybe someone specialized in breast cancer at a large cancer center. Best, Helena.

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2009 01:25AM helena67 wrote: Hi Mamita, Sorry to hear about all the stress you are going through. But it sounds to me you are getting good advice from your surgeon. Since you had 2 positive nodes (2 out of 2) it would be wise to remove more to see if there are any additional positive nodes. Normally they try to remove at least (approximately) 10 nodes. It also sounds like you had a fairly large tumor and close to the chest wall - doing a mastectomy then may be a good idea. With positive nodes you probably are going to be advised to have radiation too. Make a list of questions and get them answered. Get a second opinion if you are not comfortable. Good luck! -Helena.

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2010 12:00PM helena67 wrote: Second opinion is a good idea. But I agree with the others. Even if the second opinion doctor gives you the choice - I would go with chemo if I were in your shoes...You are young and you have a Grade 3 tumor. That's a recipe for chemo. However, regardless of what you decide, don't let others decide for you. Make sure you do what is in YOUR interest.Seek out an excellent cancer center. If needed, find a friend to drive you or take public transportation. Warm regards, Helena.
Posts.Title: StageIIA, Oncotype 17- NO CHEMO, Are you Agree? yunlee72 ColoGal

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2010 01:08AM helena67 wrote: I think one should be a bit careful to make statements that chemo will do her more harm than good. There is a difference between a grade 1 and a grade 3 tumor and this should make a difference in how this responds to chemo. For balance, I don't think that fear for chemo should prevent someone from getting an optimal treatment. But what is the optimal treatment is the question of course. Best of luck to all, -Helena.
Posts.Title: StageIIA, Oncotype 17- NO CHEMO, Are you Agree? yunlee72 ColoGal

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2009 01:19PM helena67 wrote: I don't know... I am always a bit surprised that some people put so much faith in stuff posted on a holistic website. Uncontrolled, unchecked. But it works!! Supposedly. I put my faith into mainstream medicine. It may not be perfect, but it's the best we have.

Posts.Title: 5 years out Annie62 Moissy

Posts.Content: May 14, 2009 10:52AM helena67 wrote: If I were you I would go see a neurologist. Because they can probably determine if it could be a long-term side effect from Taxotere/Taxol or if there is another neurological (nerve) reason for it. For example, a disc problem or a lack of a certain vitamin (just to give you some examples). Also, if they cannot find a nerve or muscular reason for your pain, then they can refer you to an orthopedic surgeon instead, to check out hip bones and joints, etc.  You need to see someone with knowledge in the fields of nerves/muscles/bones on one hand and pain on the other hand. Neurologist would be my first pick. Good luck, don't give up!
